title: Compliance & Audit
description: Governance, audit models, and accountability frameworks
content: Compliance & Audit > Audit models, trace discipline, override recording, and the rules that > preserve accountability Overview This section defines the compliance framework for NexusCanon and AXIS. Every decision, every action, every override is recorded and auditable. Principle: _What cannot be traced cannot be trusted._ Audit Model Immutable Trace Every system action generates an immutable trace record: - Actor — Who performed the action - Action — What was done - Target — What was affected - Timestamp — When it occurred - Context — Business justification Override Recording When standard procedures are bypassed: 1. Override reason must be documented 2. Approver must be identified 3. Impact assessment required 4. Time-bound expiration enforced Compliance Domains Financial Compliance - SOX controls integration - Revenue recognition rules - Expense approval workflows Operational Compliance - Process adherence monitoring - SLA tracking and reporting - Quality assurance checkpoints Data Governance - Data classification enforcement - Retention policy automation - Privacy controls and consent Reporting Standard Reports - Daily activity logs - Weekly compliance summaries - Monthly audit digests - Quarterly compliance reviews Ad-Hoc Queries Compliance team can query: - Specific decision chains - User activity patterns - Exception frequencies - Override justifications Related Documentation - System Overview — System capabilities - Training — Stakeholder training --- Last Updated: 2026-01-13

title: KPI Dictionary
description: Key Performance Indicator definitions and reporting logic
content: KPI Dictionary > Canonical definitions for all Key Performance Indicators tracked in > NexusCanon. Overview This dictionary defines the standard KPIs used across all business surfaces. Each KPI includes: - Definition: What the metric measures - Formula: How the metric is calculated - Source: Where the data originates - Frequency: How often the metric is updated Financial KPIs Revenue Metrics | KPI | Definition | Formula | Source | Frequency | | ------------- | ------------------------------- | ------------------------------------ | ---------- | --------- | | Gross Revenue | Total revenue before deductions | Sum(Invoice.Amount) | Accounting | Daily | | Net Revenue | Revenue after returns/discounts | Gross Revenue - Returns - Discounts | Accounting | Daily | | MRR | Monthly Recurring Revenue | Sum(ActiveSubscription.MonthlyValue) | Billing | Monthly | Profitability Metrics | KPI | Definition | Formula | Source | Frequency | | ---------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------- | ---------- | --------- | | Gross Margin | Revenue minus COGS | (Revenue - COGS) / Revenue | Accounting | Monthly | | Operating Margin | Operating income ratio | Operating Income / Revenue | Accounting | Monthly | | EBITDA | Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization | Net Income + Interest + Taxes + D&A | Accounting | Monthly | Operational KPIs Process Efficiency | KPI | Definition | Formula | Source | Frequency | | ---------------- | --------------------------------- | ----------------------------------- | ------------- | --------- | | Cycle Time | Time from order to delivery | Avg(DeliveryDate - OrderDate) | Supply Chain | Weekly | | On-Time Delivery | Orders delivered by promised date | (OnTimeOrders / TotalOrders) × 100 | Supply Chain | Weekly | | First Pass Yield | Products passing QC first time | (PassedFirst / TotalProduced) × 100 | Manufacturing | Daily | Customer Metrics | KPI | Definition | Formula | Source | Frequency | | ---------- | --------------------------- | -------------------------------------- | ------ | --------- | | NPS | Net Promoter Score | %Promoters - %Detractors | CRM | Quarterly | | CSAT | Customer Satisfaction Score | (Satisfied / TotalResponses) × 100 | CRM | Monthly | | Churn Rate | Customer attrition rate | (LostCustomers / StartCustomers) × 100 | CRM | Monthly | Governance KPIs Decision Metrics | KPI | Definition | Formula | Source | Frequency | | ----------------- | -------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------- | --------- | --------- | | Decision Velocity | Average time to ratify proposals | Avg(RatifiedDate - SubmittedDate) | BoardRoom | Weekly | | Approval Rate | Proposals approved vs submitted | (Approved / Submitted) × 100 | BoardRoom | Monthly | | Compliance Score | Audit findings addressed | (AddressedFindings / TotalFindings) × 100 | Audit | Quarterly | Reporting Logic Data Refresh Schedule | Source | Refresh Frequency | Latency | | ------------- | ------------------ | ------------ | | Accounting | Daily at 02:00 UTC | < 4 hours | | BoardRoom | Real-time | < 1 minute | | CRM | Daily at 06:00 UTC | < 2 hours | | Manufacturing | Hourly | < 15 minutes | | Supply Chain | Daily at 04:00 UTC | < 3 hours | Data Quality Rules 1. Completeness: All required fields must be populated 2. Accuracy: Values must match source system within 0.01% 3. Timeliness: Data must be available within stated latency 4. Consistency: Same calculation across all reports Related - Compliance — Audit and regulatory requirements - Process Flows — Operational workflows - Overview — System overview

title: ERP System Overview
description: Business overview of the ERP system capabilities and value
content: ERP System Overview > Comprehensive business overview of the ERP system capabilities, modules, and > value proposition System Capabilities The ERP system provides comprehensive business management across all key operational areas: - Executive Decision Making: BoardRoom module for fast, accountable decisions - Financial Management: Accounting and Finance modules for complete financial control - Customer Relations: CRM module for customer management - Operations: Manufacturing, Supply Chain, and Procurement modules - Growth: Marketing and Investor Relations modules ERP Modules BoardRoom Executive decision engine enabling zero-latency approvals with forensic accountability. Business Value: Transform decision-making from days to seconds, with complete audit trails. Accounting Complete bookkeeping and accounts management. Business Value: Accurate financial records and compliance. Finance Financial planning and analysis capabilities. Business Value: Strategic financial planning and forecasting. CRM Customer relationship management. Business Value: Improved customer satisfaction and retention. Manufacturing Production and manufacturing management. Business Value: Optimized production processes. Supply Chain Supply chain and logistics management. Business Value: Efficient supply chain operations. Procurement Procurement and vendor management. Business Value: Cost-effective procurement processes. Marketing Marketing campaign and lead management. Business Value: Improved marketing ROI. Investor Relations Investor communication and reporting. Business Value: Transparent investor relations. Business Benefits 1. Operational Efficiency: Streamlined processes across all business functions 2. Data-Driven Decisions: Real-time insights and analytics 3. Compliance: Built-in audit trails and compliance features 4. Scalability: System grows with your business 5. Integration: Seamless integration between modules ROI The ERP system delivers measurable ROI through: - Reduced decision latency (days → seconds) - Improved operational efficiency - Better financial control - Enhanced customer satisfaction - Streamlined processes Related Documentation - Training Materials - Training resources - Compliance Documentation - Compliance and audit information --- Last Updated: 2026-01-11

title: Process Flows
content: Process Flows > Canonical operational workflows across NexusCanon business domains. Overview This section documents the end-to-end business processes implemented in NexusCanon. Each process flow defines: - Trigger: What initiates the process - Steps: Sequential activities and decision points - Actors: Roles involved at each step - Outputs: Expected deliverables and records Procure-to-Pay (P2P) The complete procurement lifecycle from requisition to payment. Process Steps 1. Requisition: Department submits purchase request 2. Approval: Manager reviews and approves (or rejects) 3. Sourcing: Procurement identifies suppliers 4. Purchase Order: PO created and sent to supplier 5. Receipt: Goods/services received and inspected 6. Invoice Matching: Three-way match (PO, Receipt, Invoice) 7. Payment: Approved invoices scheduled for payment Key Actors | Role | Responsibilities | | ---------------- | ----------------------------------- | | Requisitioner | Submits purchase requests | | Approver | Reviews and authorizes spending | | Procurement | Sources suppliers, negotiates terms | | Accounts Payable | Processes invoices and payments | | Receiver | Confirms receipt of goods/services | Controls - Approval thresholds by amount - Three-way match required for payment - Segregation of duties (requester ≠ approver) Order-to-Cash (O2C) Revenue cycle from customer order to cash collection. Process Steps 1. Order Entry: Customer places order 2. Credit Check: Customer creditworthiness verified 3. Fulfillment: Order picked, packed, shipped 4. Delivery: Goods delivered to customer 5. Invoicing: Invoice generated and sent 6. Collection: Payment received and applied 7. Close: Order marked complete Key Actors | Role | Responsibilities | | ----------- | -------------------------------------- | | Sales | Captures orders, manages relationships | | Credit | Evaluates customer credit risk | | Warehouse | Fulfills and ships orders | | Billing | Generates and sends invoices | | Collections | Follows up on outstanding payments | Controls - Credit limit enforcement - Shipping confirmation required before invoicing - Aging reports for overdue accounts Record-to-Report (R2R) Financial close and reporting cycle. Process Steps 1. Transaction Recording: Daily transactions posted 2. Period Close: Subledgers closed 3. Consolidation: Entities combined 4. Adjustments: Accruals and corrections 5. Review: Management review and signoff 6. Reporting: Financial statements generated 7. Analysis: Variance analysis and commentary Key Actors | Role | Responsibilities | | ---------- | -------------------------------------- | | Accountant | Records transactions, prepares entries | | Controller | Reviews close, ensures accuracy | | CFO | Approves final statements | | Auditor | Validates controls and balances | Controls - Reconciliation required before close - Management certification - Audit trail for all adjustments Decision-to-Action (D2A) Governance process for executive decisions. Process Steps 1. Proposal: Initiative submitted to BoardRoom 2. Review: Stakeholders evaluate proposal 3. Discussion: Q&A and deliberation 4. Vote: Formal voting on proposal 5. Ratification: Decision recorded 6. Implementation: Action plan executed 7. Tracking: Progress monitored Key Actors | Role | Responsibilities | | -------- | ------------------------------------ | | Proposer | Submits initiative for consideration | | Reviewer | Evaluates feasibility and impact | | Voter | Participates in formal decision | | Executor | Implements approved decisions | Controls - Quorum requirements for voting - Conflict of interest disclosure - Decision audit trail Related - KPI Dictionary — Performance metrics - Compliance — Regulatory requirements - Overview — System overview

title: Business Training
description: Induction and training for decision-makers and stakeholders
content: Business Training > Induction paths and operational literacy for decision-makers and stakeholders Overview This section provides training resources for executives, managers, and stakeholders who need to understand and leverage the NexusCanon system. Purpose: Equip decision-makers with the knowledge to govern effectively and make informed decisions. Training Tracks Executive Track For C-suite and senior leadership: - System governance overview - Decision-making workflows - Audit and compliance understanding - Strategic reporting capabilities Management Track For department heads and managers: - Operational workflows - Team coordination features - Performance monitoring - Approval and delegation Stakeholder Track For board members and external stakeholders: - System capabilities overview - Reporting and transparency - Compliance assurance - Investor communications Key Concepts Decision Authority Understanding who can approve what: - Circle-based governance — Decisions flow through defined circles - Escalation paths — When and how decisions escalate - Override protocols — Emergency decision procedures Audit Trail Every stakeholder should understand: - How actions are recorded - How to review decision history - How to demonstrate compliance Resources - System Overview — Comprehensive system guide - Compliance & Audit — Governance framework --- Last Updated: 2026-01-13

title: Architecture
description: System architecture, boundaries, and design principles
content: Architecture > System boundaries, invariants, and architectural decisions Overview This section documents the architectural foundations of NexusCanon. Understanding these principles is essential for maintaining system integrity. Core Principles 1. Boundary Enforcement Every domain has explicit boundaries: - Data boundaries: What data each domain owns - API boundaries: How domains communicate - Event boundaries: What events each domain emits 2. Invariant Protection System invariants that must never be violated: - Audit trail completeness: Every action must be traced - Authorization consistency: Permissions are never bypassed - Data integrity: Referential integrity is maintained 3. Trade-off Documentation Every architectural decision documents: - What we gained - What we sacrificed - Why this trade-off was acceptable System Structure Domain Organization Communication Patterns | Pattern | Use Case | Example | | ------------ | ----------------- | --------------------- | | Sync API | Real-time queries | Get proposal status | | Async Events | State changes | Proposal approved | | Saga | Multi-domain ops | Cross-domain approval | Guarantees What is Guaranteed - Consistency: Eventually consistent within 5 seconds - Durability: All committed data is persisted - Auditability: Complete trace for all operations What is Optional - Real-time sync: Not guaranteed for cross-domain queries - Order preservation: Events may arrive out of order - Exactly-once: At-least-once delivery (idempotency required) Decision Records Key architectural decisions are documented in ADRs: - ADR-001: Event-Driven Architecture — Primary communication pattern between domains - ADR-002: Domain Boundary Definition — Explicit contracts and data ownership - ADR-003: Saga Pattern — Cross-domain operation coordination > Source of Truth: ADR files are maintained in Related Documentation - API Reference - Interface contracts - Execution Guides - Implementation guides --- Last Updated: 2026-01-13

title: Getting Started

Install Dependencies 3. Set Up Environment Edit with your local configuration. 4. Start Development Server The StratonHub documentation site runs at . Repository Structure Development Workflow Branch Naming Commit Convention Follow Conventional Commits: Pre-commit Checks The repository runs automated checks before each commit: - TypeScript type checking - ESLint linting - Documentation validation - Search index build Next Steps - Architecture Overview — System boundaries and design - API Reference — Interface contracts - Execution Guides — Task-focused procedures Troubleshooting pnpm install fails TypeScript errors after pull Search not working Related - Architecture - API Reference

title: BoardRoom Integration
description: Developer tutorial for integrating with the BoardRoom API
content: BoardRoom Integration > Complete tutorial for integrating external systems with the BoardRoom API Overview This tutorial guides you through integrating your application with the BoardRoom executive decision engine. What you'll learn: - Authentication with the BoardRoom API - Creating proposals programmatically - Handling approval webhooks - Best practices for production integration Prerequisites - API access credentials - Understanding of REST APIs - Development environment with HTTP client Step 1: Authentication Setup Obtain API Credentials 1. Request API credentials from your administrator 2. Store credentials securely (never commit to source control) 3. Use environment variables for credential management Authentication Flow Step 2: Create a Proposal API Endpoint Request Format Response Step 3: Handle Webhooks Configure Webhook Endpoint Register your webhook URL in the BoardRoom settings: Webhook Payload Verify Webhook Signature Step 4: Error Handling Common Error Codes | Code | Meaning | Action | | ---- | --------------- | -------------------- | | 400 | Invalid request | Check request format | | 401 | Unauthorized | Refresh token | | 403 | Forbidden | Check permissions | | 404 | Not found | Verify resource ID | | 429 | Rate limited | Implement backoff | Retry Strategy Best Practices 1. Idempotency: Use idempotency keys for proposal creation 2. Rate Limiting: Implement exponential backoff 3. Logging: Log all API interactions for debugging 4. Monitoring: Set up alerts for webhook failures Related Documentation - API Reference - Complete API documentation - BoardRoom User Guide - End-user documentation --- Last Updated: 2026-01-13

title: Search Index Pipeline

content: Search Index Pipeline > Build, validate, and deploy the StratonHub search index. Purpose The search index enables the Command Palette () and search API to find documentation. This runbook covers: 1. How the index is built 2. When to rebuild 3. How to troubleshoot failures Prerequisites - Node.js 20.11+ installed - pnpm 8.15+ installed - Working directory: Architecture Steps 1. Build the Index Expected output: 2. Verify the Index Check the index file exists and has content: 3. Test Search Locally 1. Start the dev server: 2. Open 3. Press to open Command Palette 4. Search for a known term (e.g., "BoardRoom") 5. Verify results appear Verification | Check | Expected | Command | | --------------- | -------------- | -------------------------------------------------- | | Index exists | File present | | | Index not empty | > 0 documents | | | Search works | Results return | Manual test with Cmd+K | Troubleshooting "No documents found to index" Cause: No MDX files with valid frontmatter in Solution: 1. Check MDX files exist: 2. Verify frontmatter is valid YAML 3. Ensure required fields: , , "Skipping (non-canonical frontmatter)" Cause: MDX file missing required frontmatter fields Solution: 1. Check the file path in the warning 2. Add missing fields to frontmatter 3. Required: , (developers/users/business), (tutorial/how-to/reference/explanation) Search returns empty results Cause: Index not generated or not deployed Solution: 1. Check exists 2. Rebuild: 3. Restart dev server Index outdated after adding pages Cause: Index not rebuilt after content changes Solution: 1. Index is rebuilt automatically during 2. For dev: manually run Rollback If the index is corrupted: Automation The index is built automatically: - CI/CD: runs first - Pre-commit: Consider adding to pre-commit hook for dev experience Files Referenced | File | Purpose | | ------------------------------------ | ------------------- | | | CLI entry point | | | Core indexing logic | | | TypeScript types | | | Runtime search API | | | Search UI | Related - Getting Started — Development setup - Architecture — System design

title: SDKs & Kits
description: Client libraries and development kits for NexusCanon
content: SDKs & Kits > Typed clients and pre-validated utilities for rapid integration Overview SDKs provide typed, validated interfaces to NexusCanon APIs. Use these instead of raw HTTP calls for better developer experience and fewer integration errors. Available SDKs TypeScript/JavaScript SDK Package: Features: - Full TypeScript support - Automatic retry with exponential backoff - Request/response validation - Streaming support for large datasets Quick Start: Python SDK Package: Features: - Async/await support - Pydantic models for validation - Comprehensive type hints Go SDK Package: Features: - Context support for cancellation - Structured error handling - Connection pooling Development Kits Stencil Kit Tools for creating and validating proposal stencils. - Stencil schema validation - Field type definitions - Preview rendering Testing Kit Utilities for integration testing. - Mock server - Fixture generation - Snapshot testing SDK Versioning | SDK Version | API Version | Status | | ----------- | ----------- | ------ | | 1.x | v1 | Stable | | 2.x | v2 | Beta | Related Documentation - API Reference - Raw API documentation - BoardRoom Integration - Integration guide --- Last Updated: 2026-01-13

title: Creating Proposals
description: Step-by-step guide to creating proposals in BoardRoom
content: Creating Proposals > Step-by-step guide to submitting proposals through the BoardRoom system Overview This guide walks you through the complete process of creating and submitting a proposal for executive approval. Time required: 5-10 minutes Prerequisites Before you begin: - Access to the BoardRoom module - Understanding of your organization's approval circles - Required proposal data gathered Step 1: Navigate to BoardRoom 1. From the main navigation, select BoardRoom 2. Click the New Proposal button in the top right corner 3. You will see the proposal creation wizard Step 2: Select a Stencil Stencils are pre-configured templates for common proposal types: | Stencil | Use Case | | ---------------- | ----------------------------- | | Hiring Request | New employee positions | | Budget Expansion | Department budget increases | | Vendor Approval | New vendor onboarding | | Policy Change | Organizational policy updates | 1. Browse available stencils 2. Click on the stencil that matches your proposal type 3. Review the required fields Step 3: Fill in Proposal Details Complete all required fields: - Title: Clear, descriptive proposal title - Description: Detailed explanation of the proposal - Impact: Business impact assessment - Timeline: Requested implementation timeline - Budget: Financial implications (if applicable) Step 4: Select Approval Circle 1. Choose the appropriate approval circle 2. Review the approvers who will receive the proposal 3. Confirm the escalation path Step 5: Review and Submit 1. Preview your complete proposal 2. Verify all information is accurate 3. Click Submit for Approval 4. Note your case number for tracking What Happens Next After submission: 1. Approvers receive notification 2. Track status in My Proposals 3. Respond to any clarification requests 4. Receive decision notification Troubleshooting Cannot find the right stencil Contact your system administrator to request a new stencil type. Submission button is disabled Ensure all required fields are completed. Red asterisks indicate missing data. Related Documentation - BoardRoom Overview - Complete user guide - Training - Training materials --- Last Updated: 2026-01-13

title: BoardRoom User Guide
description: Complete user guide for the BoardRoom module
content: BoardRoom User Guide > Complete guide for using the BoardRoom executive decision engine Overview BoardRoom is the executive decision engine that enables fast, accountable decision-making for your organization. Purpose: Transform executive governance from "Slow Email" to "Fast Boardroom" with zero-latency decisions and forensic accountability. Key Features: - Proposal creation and management - Real-time approval workflows - Audit trail tracking - Decision impact analysis Quick Start Get started with BoardRoom in 3 steps: 1. Create a Proposal: Navigate to BoardRoom and click "New Proposal" 2. Fill in Details: Use the stencil form to provide proposal information 3. Submit for Approval: Submit to the appropriate circle for review Getting Started Creating Your First Proposal 1. Navigate to the BoardRoom module 2. Click the "New Proposal" button 3. Select a stencil (e.g., "Hiring Request", "Budget Expansion") 4. Fill in the required fields 5. Submit for approval Understanding Proposal Status - DRAFT: Proposal is being created - SUBMITTED: Proposal is awaiting approval - APPROVED: Proposal has been approved - VETOED: Proposal has been rejected Common Tasks Submitting a Proposal 1. Create a new proposal 2. Fill in all required fields 3. Review the proposal details 4. Click "Submit for Approval" 5. Select the appropriate circle 6. Confirm submission Tracking Proposal Status 1. Navigate to "My Proposals" 2. View the status of each proposal 3. Click on a proposal to see details 4. Review the approval history Troubleshooting Issue: Cannot submit proposal Symptoms: Submit button is disabled or shows an error Cause: Required fields are missing or invalid Solution: Review the form and ensure all required fields are filled correctly Issue: Proposal not appearing in list Symptoms: Created proposal doesn't show in proposals list Cause: Browser cache or filter settings Solution: Refresh the page or check filter settings Related Documentation - API Reference - Technical API documentation - Training Materials - Training resources --- Last Updated: 2026-01-11

title: Roles & Permissions
description: Role definitions and permission matrix for operators
content: Roles & Permissions > Understand your access level and what actions you can perform. Overview NexusCanon uses Role-Based Access Control (RBAC). Your role determines: - What surfaces you can access - What actions you can perform - What data you can view Standard Roles Viewer Purpose: Read-only access for monitoring and reporting. | Surface | View | Create | Edit | Delete | Approve | | ------------- | ---- | ------ | ---- | ------ | ------- | | BoardRoom | ✓ | — | — | — | — | | Accounting | ✓ | — | — | — | — | | CRM | ✓ | — | — | — | — | | Manufacturing | ✓ | — | — | — | — | | Supply Chain | ✓ | — | — | — | — | Operator Purpose: Day-to-day transaction processing. | Surface | View | Create | Edit | Delete | Approve | | ------------- | ---- | ------ | ---- | ------ | ------- | | BoardRoom | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | — | | Accounting | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | — | | CRM | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | — | | Manufacturing | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | — | | Supply Chain | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | — | Approver Purpose: Review and approve submissions. | Surface | View | Create | Edit | Delete | Approve | | ------------- | ---- | ------ | ---- | ------ | ------- | | BoardRoom | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | ✓ | | Accounting | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | ✓ | | CRM | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | ✓ | | Manufacturing | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | ✓ | | Supply Chain | ✓ | ✓ | Own | — | ✓ | Administrator Purpose: Full control over a surface. | Surface | View | Create | Edit | Delete | Approve | | ---------------- | ---- | ------ | ---- | ------ | ------- | | Assigned Surface | ✓ | ✓ | All | ✓ | ✓ | | Other Surfaces | ✓ | — | — | — | — | Super Admin Purpose: System-wide administration (restricted). | Surface | View | Create | Edit | Delete | Approve | | ------------- | ---- | ------ | ---- | ------ | ------- | | All Surfaces | ✓ | ✓ | All | ✓ | ✓ | | System Config | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ | Permission Definitions | Permission | Description | | -------------- | ------------------------------- | | View | Can see records and reports | | Create | Can create new records | | Edit (Own) | Can modify records they created | | Edit (All) | Can modify any record | | Delete | Can remove records | | Approve | Can approve/reject submissions | Requesting Access Changes Escalation Path 1. Submit request to your direct manager 2. Manager approves and forwards to IT Security 3. IT Security validates and provisions access 4. You receive confirmation email Temporary Elevation For time-limited elevated access: 1. Submit elevation request with business justification 2. Security review (SLA: 4 hours) 3. Access granted with automatic expiry 4. Audit log created Session & Security Session Timeout | Activity Level | Timeout | | ---------------- | ---------------- | | Active use | 8 hours | | Idle | 30 minutes | | Sensitive action | Re-auth required | Multi-Factor Authentication Required for: - All Approver and above roles - Access to sensitive data - Administrative actions Audit Trail All permission-related actions are logged: - Login/logout events - Permission changes - Access denials - Elevation requests Related - Training — Onboarding and certification - BoardRoom Guide — Using the decision engine

title: Operator Training
description: Training materials and onboarding guides for operators
content: Operator Training > Guided onboarding and operational literacy for consistent execution Overview This section provides structured training paths for operators entering the NexusCanon system. Purpose: Ensure every operator has the knowledge required to execute with precision and maintain audit-ready discipline. Training Modules Module 1: System Orientation - Understanding NexusCanon architecture - Navigating AXIS surfaces - Role-based access and permissions Module 2: Operational Discipline - Standard operating procedures - Trace discipline and audit trails - Error handling and escalation Module 3: Surface Mastery Each AXIS surface has dedicated training: - BoardRoom — Executive decision engine - Accounting — Bookkeeping and ledger management - Finance — Financial planning and analysis - CRM — Customer relationship management - Manufacturing — Production workflows - Supply Chain — Logistics coordination - Procurement — Vendor and purchase management - Marketing — Campaign execution - Investor Relations — Stakeholder communication Certification Path 1. Foundation — Complete orientation modules 2. Practitioner — Demonstrate surface proficiency 3. Expert — Lead operational workflows --- Last Updated: 2026-01-13
